comments.commentBody:
The most convoluted theory of this years polling is the notion that Trump has extra voters that will say Clinton but vote Trump.
The theory is in fact upside down.
There are boisterous fake Trump voters that will in fact switch to Clinton in the voting booth.
One only has to look at preponderance of negative realizations about how unsuitable and dangerous Trump is in hard cold facts. It will be the Trump voters that switch and retreat on Election Day.
Cohn is fascinating no one by feinting a twist in demographic impact, the demographics are still and will always be true....he is toying with attribution. This race is not anywhere near as close as we are being lead to believe.
What Trump needs to happen on November 8, 2016 is an highly unlikely occurance. The Swing states polling has a history of being anti incumbent party by 1.5-2% that won't appear Election Day. This is possibly attributable to those voters having a sense of destiny in their hands, but in the end they vote for the favorite over the insurgent.

Why? Why vote for HRC?  How anyone could reasonably believe that Hillary would not continue to lie and coverup is beyond all comprehensive thinking of anyone regardless of their race! What I hope to see is a very nice long retirement in her old age!  Be well and send a postcard!

Two words spell trouble for Hillary: Enthusiasm Gap

Two words spell victory for Trump: Extreme Enthusiasm.

Among the base.
And where is Bernie Sanders, so beloved by the young?  Has he been on the campaign trail at all for her?  Seems like we haven't heard or seen much from him in the past couple months.

Whether 1% or 0.1%, so long as she wins, it's all good.

Now get out and vote!
I think its time to begin to accept that Hillary is going to lose.  She's not going to be president and it'll hurt less if you start getting used to it.

Think about this for a minute - Most of the people who will vote for Trump on Election Day would never admit that to a pollster.

The polls are useless this year, and a disaster beckons.

I didn't like Nate Cohn when he was using all his graphs and other nonsense to keep Bernie Sanders down. And I think he's just as full of it now.

Orange, NJ
Can we all get down on our knees and beg Bernie to take her place?

Let's all face it, HRC should be leading Trump by double digits, everywhere.

That's not happening and the race is getting tighter. Why? Because much more so that Trump, HRC is her own worst enemy, as witnessed this weekend.

She is blinded by a naked ambition, shrouded in unnecessary secrecy, and deluded in the perverse thinking that the presidency is her right.

The coronation ain't happening. Almost any other Dem would run away with this election, given the opponent.

There is deep, deep distrust and resentment of the Clinton attitude of entitlement. And I don't think the polls accurately reflect that, and we are all in for a big, unpleasant surprise in November. Johnson is pulling away all of the many, many disaffected Dem voters, like me, and Hillary will be left with...... Bill

They deserve each other, they really do. Pariahs stick together.

"Calling Vladimir V. Putin, the Russian president, “a thug and a butcher,” Mr. McCain said Mr. Trump’s embrace of the autocratic ruler was unacceptable, according to a Republican official present who also insisted on anonymity."

And yet John McCain supports and endorses Donald Trump for president.

As a Latino from Colorado, my family is exactly the demographic Hillary needs to win key states, and as a Hillary supporter trying to convince skeptical relatives, I can shed light on her struggles with the Latino community. Above all, it's a perceived lack of engagement with us and our concerns. Someone in Hillary's campaign has decided to take the Latino vote for granted, presuming our dislike of Trump is enough to bring us to vote for Hillary. But this alone is not enough to spur Latino voter turnout.

In 2012, for example, Obama's campaign showed clear hustle in reaching out to us, sending reps and campaigners to us as early as May, helping us to register, aggressively campaigning on the Spanish TV, radio channels and print, inviting us to contribute our concerns in forums, overall making it clear he cared and wanted our vote. FWIW immigration is actually a much less important concern for us, OTOH stagnant wages, the healthcare mess and education (in both traditional and Spanish two-way immersion schools) are very important.

Hillary's campaign has done comparatively little, almost no ads on Spanish media despite her immense warchest, little direct engagement or soliciting our concerns. It's clear she's better which is why I'm voting for her, but we're very busy people often working multiple jobs, and most Latinos don't get the sense she really cares that much to earn our votes. That's just the reality, but fortunately she can fix it.

as a Clinton campaign volunteer, I know we are targeting our voters and getting them to vote early. not one word in this article about ground game and let me tell you ours is tops. we have tens of thousands of people in all fifty states phone banking and canvasing. in particular we have Spanish, Cantonese and Mandarin phone-banks. I also believe this discounts the Latino Decisions polling which is in Spanish are far more accurate. Hillary has a long history of advocating for the rights of Latinos and they are ready and anxious to not only vote against Trump but vote affirmatively for her. We're with her and she's with us!

replies.commentBody: 68 actually, so it's worse for her among these groups.
What does a 70 yr old Billionaire have in common? Much less, I bet.

comments.commentBody:
She's has overestimated the black vote.

She's a 60 year old, white, woman, millionaire.

What does she possibly have in common with blacks that they can identify with.

Unless she's a Chameleon, she can't count on that vote.

A child can see that....

replies.commentBody: The key to this election will not only depend on one particular demographic group.

comments.commentBody: The key to this election will be College educated white people. Will they swing to Clinton in larger numbers than they have swung Republican in previous elections. The Bernie bots and mainstream media have had it all wrong. There's no "Revolution" in this country.The key for Clinton has always been to swing suburban Republicans (Republicans with a brain)

In reality the Clintons are a part of the white elite who have earned their millions by exploiting minorities and Hispanics as bargaining chips in their presidential stakes. I'm one of the deplorables voting for Trump b/c at least we know what he is, a vicious and unethical businessman but unlike the Clintons who fashion themselves into the "White savior" and pretend to be just like "us" (as long as they vote for Clintons otherwise its gonesky), Trump doesn't nee to pretend.

Funny incident the other day. I was debating my liberal friends at the bowling alley and alluded to the destruction of 13 cellphone by the application of hammers, much like lower street level drug dealers do, and watched as my friends just covered their ears--- like please don't tell me how bad it really is cause I just might change my vote or simply stay home. Really?

It's apples and oranges. A black presidential candidate was all the rage back in 2008. Hillary Clinton? Been there, done that.

But this time the race is between two white candidates and the difference this time is good and evil as opposed to the novelty of having a black President.

Trump is a nightmare in waiting and Clinton is the only logical choice for sane people.

I am absolutely shocked that the race is as close as it is.

It's the Television culture versus civilization rooted in reality.

"The end result: According to The Upshot’s estimates, Mrs. Clinton’s gains from demographic change could be as small as a single percentage point."

Good news! Since white privilege is not under the great demographic threat that all those old white guys feared, I guess they can all save the expenditure of energy necessary to get to the polls and sit this one out.

I think there are two factors that are not covered by the analysis.

The first is that older, white Christian voters are passing on to their heavenly rewards (or not)...and are not being replaced by younger, white Christian voters with "traditional" values. This translates to Mr. Trump having less support than some might assume. It is unclear to me that the current polls are picking up on this fact.

Second---this is going to be an election where voter turnout is going to be especially important. Secretary Clinton theoretically has an robust ground game....and if proves effective we may see a higher voter turn out from minority groups than is projected.

I will never again be bullied into voting for the Dems because they are so superior to the other.
voting for Jill Stein. We need more parties and more debate. Make everyone happy.

All of a sudden Hillary is redoing what Bill undid and why didn't Obama do more for women whatever color? BTW the fastest growing segment of society is woefully under utilized. Retirees could certainly offer additional hands, laps in day care and pre school. Locating centers as for Headstart is more problematic. Some people with no ed in education are absolutely fantastic and I believe some women on welfare used to HAVE to help out in daycare. They were among the best.!

replies.commentBody:
Even I can answer this for you. The answers are all over the internet. The answers can be found in numerous interviews.

Hillary grew up in a Republican Household - it's obvious that would have shaped her views. She was a goldwater girl before she was able to vote.

She made an ideological shift while attending Wellesley, reading Saul Alinsky and seeing MLK give a speech had a profound impact on her.

The information is out there, she may need to repeat it over and over and over and over because the electorate refuses to inform itself.

comments.commentBody: Secretary Clinton, please explain to your African American/Hispanic voters what made you transform from a "Goldwater Girl" into a more all-inclusive social reform advocate, while at the same time calling Trump and his supporters "deplorable"? Would you say that your views in your youth/early college years were consistent with Trump and many of his supporters now and do you think your presidency will assist in the country's social evolution?  An honest and candid conversation in front of a National audience would significantly improve her credibility and bring on-the-fence minorities back into the Democratic party with hope for real change.
When people cast their vote, reality will hit them. Do they want the surgeon to operate on them, or the janitor?

The Democrats thought inevitable Demographic changes would AUTOMATICALLY give them a permanent majority and so they not only wrote off white voters, they returned to the couch, binge watched Downton Abbey and munched on argula salad confident that no effort was needed to win elections.

They lost the House in 2010 and the Senate in 2014 and like canaries in the coal mine chalked it up to the fact that it was the midterms and they don't count.

According to Ruy Texeria, Az and Texas should have been well on their way to being "blue" by now, yet both states get "redder" every election cycle.

Problem number one is that the Latino voter does not show up at polls, voting at less than 50% of eligible compared to 64% for white and black voters.

For Latinos, jobs and the economy are more important issues than immigration yet the Democrats focus on Trump's Wall to the exclusion of all else.

In Arizona, registered independents outnumber registered Democrats and both each lag registered Republicans.
McCain will win by double digits.
Kirkpatrick's vacated seat goes Republican.
Sheriff Joe wins a SEVENTH term.

Dems putting all their eggs in the demographic basket may just make Republicans a permanent majority.
I hate to bring this up, but a number of Hispanic and black men are misogynistic.

Let's look at this from another angle. A year ago, when people still thought that Hillary Clinton was going to be running against Jeb Bush, nobody expected Hillary to get the same minority support as Barack Obama did. We expected her to get 70-80% of a moderate turnout, like her husband did when he ran, not 95% of a record breaking turnout that Obama got. And we expected Bush, who was a moderate on immigration and the husband of a Mexican American to keep it a little closer among Latinos Romney or McCain had. Instead we got Trump with his massive unpopularity among non-white voters. so yes, Hillary is going to crush Trump on the minority vote... but no moreso than Barack Obama did, and understandably so. When the bar is set that high, it's great that she's coming anywhere near matching it.
